ADMISSION NOTE
Patient: JOHNSON, ALEX
Unit No: 12345678
Date of Birth: 1952-07-22 (72 years old)
Date: 03/15/2024, 14:30
Admission via: Emergency Department
Attending: Dr. Sarah Chen
Service: MEDICINE

CHIEF COMPLAINT: Cough and fever x4 days

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
72-year-old male with past medical history significant for COPD on home O2 2L continuous, type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia presenting to ED with 4 days of productive cough and fever. Patient states he has been feeling "run down" since Monday (4 days ago) with progressive cough productive of yellowish sputum. Reports fever at home measured up to 101.5°F. Also notes increased shortness of breath compared to baseline, even with home oxygen. States his breathing has been "heavier" and he's had to sit down more frequently when moving around his apartment. Denies chest pain, though does report some right-sided chest discomfort with deep inspiration. Denies nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea but notes decreased PO intake over past 2 days due to fatigue and poor appetite. No abdominal pain. Patient has not been taking any over-the-counter medications. Denies recent sick contacts, travel, or known TB exposure.

Patient called his PCP office this morning (Dr. Maria Martinez) and was advised to come to ED given fever, productive cough, and known COPD. 

In ED (arrival 11:45 AM):
- Initial vitals: Temp 102.1°F, BP 108/65, HR 95, RR 22, O2 sat 89% on room air
- Appeared ill and in mild respiratory distress
- Placed on 2L NC with improvement to O2 sat 94%
- Labs drawn (see below)
- CXR obtained showing RLL infiltrate
- Blood cultures x2 drawn
- Started on IV NS 500mL bolus for mild hypotension
- Given acetaminophen 650mg PO for fever
- Discussed with admitting team, plan for admission for IV antibiotics

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. COPD - diagnosed 2015, on home oxygen 2L continuous since 2020, multiple exacerbations requiring oral steroids, last hospitalization 8 months ago for COPD exacerbation, PFTs 2023 showed FEV1 48% predicted (moderate obstruction)
2. Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus - diagnosed 2018, managed with metformin, last A1C 7.2% (6 months ago)
3. Hypertension - well-controlled on lisinopril
4. Hyperlipidemia - on statin therapy
5. History of tobacco use disorder - quit 2020

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
- Appendectomy (1975)
- Right knee arthroscopy (2010)

HOME MEDICATIONS (confirmed with patient and pharmacy at 617-555-9876):
1. Metformin 1000mg PO BID (takes with meals)
2. Lisinopril 10mg PO daily (takes in AM)
3. Atorvastatin 20mg PO daily (takes at bedtime)
4. Albuterol HFA inhaler 90mcg - 2 puffs Q4H PRN SOB/wheeze
5. Home oxygen 2L continuous via nasal cannula

ALLERGIES: NKDA (No Known Drug Allergies)

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Patient lives alone in apartment at 123 Oak Street, Boston MA 02118. Retired electrician (retired 2017). Independent with ADLs and IADLs. Has visiting nurse who comes weekly to check vitals and medication compliance. Daughter lives nearby (Watertown) and visits 2-3x/week, does grocery shopping for patient. Former smoker - 30 pack-year history (1 PPD x 30 years), quit 4 years ago (2020) with help of nicotine patch and Chantix. Denies alcohol or illicit drug use.

FAMILY HISTORY:
Father deceased (MI at age 68). Mother deceased (stroke at age 75). One brother alive with diabetes. No family history of lung cancer or other malignancies.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
Constitutional: Positive for fever, chills, fatigue, decreased appetite. Denies weight loss (though hasn't weighed himself recently).
HEENT: Denies headache, vision changes, hearing changes, sore throat, rhinorrhea.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain (aside from pleuritic discomfort), palpitations, orthopnea, PND, lower extremity edema.
Respiratory: As per HPI - productive cough with yellow sputum, worsening SOB, pleuritic chest pain. Denies hemoptysis.
GI: Decreased PO intake as noted. Denies N/V/D, abdominal pain, melena, hematochezia.
GU: Denies dysuria, hematuria, frequency.
MSK: Denies joint pain or swelling.
Neuro: Denies weakness, numbness, tingling, seizures, LOC.
Psych: Denies depression, anxiety.
All other systems reviewed and negative.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
Vitals: Temp 102.1°F (Tmax 102.1), BP 108/65, HR 95, RR 22, O2 sat 89% RA → 94% on 2L NC
General: 72yo male appearing ill and fatigued, mild respiratory distress with slightly increased work of breathing, able to speak in full sentences but pauses occasionally
HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. PERRL, EOMI. Sclerae anicteric. Dry mucous membranes (poor PO intake). Oropharynx clear without erythema or exudate. No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.
Neck: Supple, trachea midline, no JVD at 30 degrees, no thyromegaly
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1/S2, no murmurs/rubs/gallops appreciated. PMI non-displaced. 2+ radial and DP pulses bilaterally.
Pulmonary: Tachypneic with RR 22. Mild increased work of breathing. Decreased breath sounds at right lower lobe with crackles/rales heard posteriorly RLL. Left lung clear. No wheezes. Dullness to percussion at RLL. Tactile fremitus increased RLL. No egophony appreciated (patient difficulty with "E to A" testing due to dyspnea).
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended. Normoactive bowel sounds. No hepatosplenomegaly. No rebound or guarding.
Extremities: Warm, well-perfused. No cyanosis or clubbing. No lower extremity edema. Cap refill <2 sec.
Skin: No rashes or lesions noted.
Neurologic: Alert and oriented x3 (person, place, time). CN II-XII grossly intact. Strength 5/5 in all extremities. Sensation intact to light touch. Gait not assessed (patient on oxygen).

LABORATORY DATA (drawn in ED at 12:00):
CBC:
- WBC 12.5 K/uL (elevated, left shift noted: 82% neutrophils, 8% bands)
- Hemoglobin 13.2 g/dL
- Hematocrit 39.8%
- Platelets 245 K/uL
- MCV 89 fL

BMP:
- Sodium 138 mEq/L
- Potassium 4.1 mEq/L
- Chloride 102 mEq/L
- CO2 24 mEq/L
- BUN 22 mg/dL (mildly elevated, likely pre-renal from dehydration)
- Creatinine 1.1 mg/dL (at baseline per records)
- Glucose 145 mg/dL (mildly elevated, patient diabetic)
- Calcium 9.2 mg/dL

LFTs:
- AST 28 U/L
- ALT 32 U/L
- Alk Phos 78 U/L
- Total Bilirubin 0.8 mg/dL

Other:
- Lactate 1.4 mmol/L (normal, adequate perfusion)
- Procalcitonin 2.8 ng/mL (elevated, suggestive of bacterial infection)

Arterial Blood Gas (on 2L NC):
- pH 7.40
- pCO2 42 mmHg
- pO2 68 mmHg
- HCO3 25 mEq/L
- O2 sat 94%

MICROBIOLOGY:
- Blood cultures x2 sets drawn at 12:15 (pending)
- Sputum culture sent (pending - good quality sample, >25 WBCs/hpf, <10 epithelial cells)
- Urine legionella antigen (pending)
- Urine pneumococcal antigen (pending)

IMAGING:
Chest X-ray (PA and lateral, 03/15/2024 12:30):
"Right lower lobe consolidation with air bronchograms consistent with pneumonia. No pleural effusion. No pneumothorax. Heart size normal. Hyperinflated lungs consistent with COPD. Left lung clear."

EKG (03/15/2024 12:45):
"Normal sinus rhythm at 92 bpm. Normal axis. Normal intervals. No ST-T changes. No old EKG available for comparison per system."

ASSESSMENT & PLAN:
72-year-old male with COPD on home O2, DM2, presenting with community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) evidenced by 4 days of productive cough, fever, hypoxemia, leukocytosis with left shift, elevated procalcitonin, and RLL infiltrate on CXR.

CURB-65 Score: 2 points (Age >65, BUN >19) - moderate risk
PSI Score: Class III (low risk for 30-day mortality)

# INFECTIOUS DISEASE - COMMUNITY-ACQUIRED PNEUMONIA
- Admit to medical floor (telemetry not needed, hemodynamically stable)
- Empiric IV antibiotics per CAP guidelines:
  * Ceftriaxone 1g IV daily (covers S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae)
  * Azithromycin 500mg IV daily (covers atypicals - Mycoplasma, Legionella, Chlamydia)
- Duration: Transition to PO when afebrile >24h and clinically improved, complete 5-7 day course
- Await culture data (blood, sputum, urine antigens)
- Acetaminophen 650mg PO Q6H PRN fever (scheduled for first 24-48h)
- Monitor clinical response: fever curve, WBC trend, oxygen requirement
- Repeat CXR if not improving by hospital day 3

# RESPIRATORY - COPD
- Continue home O2 at 2L continuous (baseline)
- May need to increase if hypoxemic, goal O2 sat 88-92% (avoid hyperoxia given COPD)
- Continue home albuterol inhaler Q4H PRN
- Hold on systemic steroids for now (no evidence of COPD exacerbation, this is infectious process)
- Incentive spirometry at bedside
- Will consider adding standing bronchodilators if increased wheezing develops

# CARDIOVASCULAR - HYPOTENSION (RESOLVED)
- BP 108/65 in ED, improved to 118/72 after 500mL NS bolus
- Likely mild dehydration from poor PO intake
- Continue IV NS at 75 mL/hr for hydration
- Monitor BP, may need to hold lisinopril if persistently low (will reassess daily)
- Telemetry not indicated at this time

# ENDOCRINE - TYPE 2 DIABETES MELLITUS  
- Hold home metformin while NPO/acute illness
- Start insulin sliding scale (see order set)
- Check BG AC and HS
- Resume home metformin when tolerating regular diet

# HYPERTENSION
- Continue lisinopril 10mg PO daily (hold if SBP <100)
- Monitor BP daily

# HYPERLIPIDEMIA
- Continue atorvastatin 20mg PO daily

# FLUIDS/NUTRITION
- IV NS at 75 mL/hr
- Diet: Regular diet, encourage PO fluids
- Speech/swallow evaluation not needed (no dysphagia reported)

# PROPHYLAXIS
- DVT: Ambulatory, encourage mobilization. Heparin 5000 units SQ TID if becomes bedbound
- GI: No indication for PPI
- Bowel regimen: Docusate 100mg PO BID PRN (given narcotics not needed)

# CODE STATUS: FULL CODE (discussed with patient, confirmed)

# DISPOSITION
- Admit to medical floor
- Anticipated length of stay: 3-4 days pending clinical improvement
- Will need follow-up CXR in 6 weeks as outpatient to ensure resolution (given age, smoking history - ensure no underlying malignancy)

Plan discussed in detail with patient. Patient verbalizes understanding and agreement with plan. All questions answered. Will continue to update patient and daughter (Jane Johnson, cell 617-555-4567, has healthcare proxy, documented in chart) on progress.

MICROBIOLOGY UPDATES:

IMAGING:
Chest X-ray (PA and lateral, 03/17/2024 07:00):
"Interval improvement in right lower lobe consolidation. Residual patchy opacity RLL but significantly improved from 03/15. No new infiltrates. No pleural effusion. No pneumothorax. Heart size normal."

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION:
General: Well-appearing 72yo male, no acute distress, comfortable, sitting up in chair eating breakfast
HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. PERRL, EOMI. Moist mucous membranes (improved hydration). Oropharynx clear.
Neck: Supple, no JVD, no LAD
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, normal S1/S2, no m/r/g, well-perfused

Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, normoactive bowel sounds
Extremities: Warm, well-perfused, no edema, no cyanosis
Neuro: Alert and oriented x3, pleasant, conversant, no focal deficits
Skin: No rashes

ASSESSMENT & PLAN:
72-year-old male with COPD, DM2 admitted on 03/15 with community-acquired pneumonia (S. pneumoniae per sputum culture) now hospital day 3 with excellent clinical response to IV antibiotics. Patient afebrile >48 hours, WBC normalized, significant symptomatic improvement, repeat CXR showing improvement. Ready for discharge today on oral antibiotics to complete therapy.

# INFECTIOUS DISEASE - COMMUNITY-ACQUIRED PNEUMONIA (IMPROVING)
- Excellent clinical response to ceftriaxone + azithromycin
- Sputum culture grew S. pneumoniae (penicillin-sensitive, as expected for community-acquired)
- Afebrile >48h, WBC normalized, symptoms markedly improved
- CXR shows interval improvement
- **PLAN: DISCHARGE TODAY**
- Transition to PO antibiotics: Azithromycin 250mg PO daily x 3 more days (total 5-day course - Days 4, 5, 6 as outpatient)
  * Why azithromycin: Covers S. pneumoniae per sensitivities, also provides atypical coverage, good lung penetration, once-daily dosing for compliance, patient has done well on it
  * Could use amoxicillin instead, but azithromycin preferred given once-daily dosing and patient reliability with medications
- Duration: Total 5 days of therapy (3 days IV + 3 days PO = 6 days total) - adequate for uncomplicated CAP with excellent response
- Patient educated on completing full course
- Follow-up CXR in 6 weeks (will arrange with PCP) to ensure complete resolution - important given age >65 and smoking history to r/o underlying lesion

# RESPIRATORY - COPD (STABLE)
- Patient back to baseline respiratory status
- Successfully weaned off supplemental O2 as of yesterday evening (03/16 @ 20:00), maintaining sats 95-97% on RA
- **DISCHARGE PLAN:** Resume home O2 2L continuous at baseline
- Continue albuterol inhaler PRN
- No COPD exacerbation component to this hospitalization
- Encouraged smoking cessation maintenance (patient quit 2020, has been abstinent)

# CARDIOVASCULAR - HYPERTENSION (CONTROLLED)
- BP well controlled on home lisinopril
- Continue lisinopril 10mg PO daily

# ENDOCRINE - TYPE 2 DIABETES MELLITUS (CONTROLLED)
- Blood sugars well controlled on home metformin
- Restarted metformin 1000mg PO BID on 03/16 when tolerating PO
- No insulin needed during hospitalization (sliding scale never triggered)
- A1C 7.2% from 6 months ago per records - reasonable control
- Continue home metformin

# HYPERLIPIDEMIA
- Continue atorvastatin 20mg PO daily

# DISPOSITION - DISCHARGE TODAY
**Discharge Medications:**
1. Azithromycin 250mg PO daily - take for 3 MORE days (03/18, 03/19, 03/20) to complete treatment - **NEW**
2. Metformin 1000mg PO BID - continue (home medication)
3. Lisinopril 10mg PO daily - continue (home medication)
4. Atorvastatin 20mg PO daily - continue (home medication)  
5. Albuterol HFA inhaler 2 puffs Q4H PRN shortness of breath - continue (home medication)
6. Home oxygen 2L continuous via nasal cannula - continue (home medical equipment)

**Discharge Instructions:**
- Complete full course of azithromycin through 03/21 (3 more days after discharge)
- Return to baseline home O2 at 2L continuous
- Resume regular diet, encourage adequate PO fluid intake
- May resume normal activities as tolerated
- **Return to ED or call 911 for:** fever >101°F, worsening shortness of breath, chest pain, coughing up blood, confusion, or any other concerning symptoms
- Follow-up with PCP Dr. Maria Martinez on **03/25/2024 at 2:00 PM** (appointment already scheduled)
  * Will need follow-up CXR in 6 weeks (approximately 04/28/2024) to ensure complete resolution of pneumonia - PCP will order
  * Address: 456 Medical Plaza, Boston MA 02115
  * Phone: (617) 555-0123

**Discharge Disposition:** Home (patient lives alone, independent with ADLs, daughter lives nearby and will check on him)

**Discharge Diagnosis:**
- PRIMARY: Community-acquired pneumonia (Streptococcus pneumoniae)
- SECONDARY: COPD on home O2, Type 2 diabetes mellitus, Hypertension, Hyperlipidemia

**Discharge Condition:**
- Mental Status: Clear and coherent
- Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive
- Activity Status: Ambulatory - independent (baseline functional status)

**Code Status:** Full code

Discharge paperwork completed. Prescriptions sent electronically to patient's pharmacy (CVS on Washington St per patient preference). Patient given paper prescriptions as backup. Discharge instructions reviewed in detail with patient - patient verbalizes understanding. Follow-up appointment confirmed. Patient agreeable to discharge plan. Daughter Jane Johnson (cell 617-555-4567) called and updated on discharge, will pick up patient from hospital.

Case discussed with Dr. Sarah Chen (attending). Dr. Chen agrees with discharge plan.

Patient medically cleared for discharge at 11:30 AM on 03/17/2024.

ADMISSION NOTE
Patient: WILLIAMS, SARAH JANE
Unit No: 87654321
Date of Birth: 1966-11-14 (58 years old)
Date: 02/28/2024, 06:15 AM
Admission via: Emergency Department - STEMI ALERT
Attending: Dr. Michael Thompson
Service: CARDIOLOGY

CHIEF COMPLAINT: Chest pain

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS:
58-year-old female with past medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia presenting as STEMI alert with acute chest pain. Patient reports she woke up at approximately 6:00 AM this morning with sudden onset of severe substernal chest pressure, described as "elephant sitting on my chest," rated 8/10 in severity. Pain radiates to left arm and jaw. Associated with diaphoresis, nausea (no vomiting), and sense of impending doom. Denies any preceding symptoms or exertional component - was at rest in bed when symptoms began. No prior history of similar chest pain. Husband called 911 immediately.

EMS arrived at 6:08 AM. Initial vitals: BP 145/92, HR 98, O2 sat 97% RA. EKG in field showed ST elevations V2-V4. Patient given aspirin 324mg chewed, sublingual nitroglycerin x2 (minimal relief), morphine 4mg IV. Transported emergently to our ED with "Code STEMI" activation.

ED arrival 6:25 AM:
- Repeat EKG confirmed anterior STEMI with 3-4mm STE V2-V4, reciprocal STD II, III, aVF
- Labs drawn including cardiac enzymes (troponin I 0.05, elevated)
- Given: Additional ASA 162mg, clopidogrel 600mg loading dose, heparin bolus 4000 units + drip at 1000 units/hr, morphine 2mg IV for pain
- Cardiology fellow paged emergently (Dr. James Rodriguez)
- Cath lab activated - team arrived within 15 minutes
- Consent obtained for emergent cardiac catheterization +/- PCI
- Patient taken to cath lab at 07:30 AM (door-to-cath time: 65 minutes)

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:
1. Hypertension - diagnosed 2019, currently on lisinopril, BP generally well-controlled per PCP records (last visit 01/15/2024 showed BP 128/78)
2. Hyperlipidemia - diagnosed 2021, on simvastatin 20mg daily, last lipid panel 6 months ago showed total chol 220, LDL 148 (not at goal)
3. Strong family history of premature CAD (see below)

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:
- Cesarean section x2 (1995, 1998)
- Tonsillectomy (childhood)

HOME MEDICATIONS (confirmed with patient and husband, also verified with CVS pharmacy 617-555-2345):
1. Lisinopril 5mg PO daily (takes in morning with breakfast)
2. Simvastatin 20mg PO daily (takes at bedtime)
** No aspirin or other antiplatelet therapy prior to today

ALLERGIES: NKDA (No Known Drug Allergies)

SOCIAL HISTORY:
Patient works as high school math teacher at Lincoln High School in Cambridge. Lives at 456 Elm Avenue, Cambridge MA 02138 with husband Robert Williams (present at bedside). Two adult children, both healthy. Never smoker - denies any tobacco use ever. Rare alcohol use (glass of wine on special occasions, less than 1 drink per week on average). No illicit drug use. Exercises occasionally - walks 2-3x/week, no formal exercise program. Diet: admits to "could be better," eats out frequently due to busy work schedule.

FAMILY HISTORY:
*** SIGNIFICANT for premature CAD ***
- Father: Myocardial infarction at age 55, underwent CABG at age 60, died age 68 from second MI
- Mother: Alive, age 82, has hypertension and diabetes
- Paternal uncle: MI in his 50s
- No family history of sudden cardiac death, arrhythmias, or cardiomyopathy

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS:
Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, recent weight changes
Cardiovascular: As per HPI - acute chest pain, diaphoresis. Denies prior angina, palpitations, syncope, orthopnea, PND, lower extremity edema
Respiratory: Denies dyspnea at baseline, cough, wheezing
GI: Nausea as noted (no vomiting). Denies abdominal pain, change in bowel habits, melena, hematochezia
All other systems reviewed and negative

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION (in ED prior to cath):
Vitals: T 98.4°F, BP 142/88 (right arm), HR 95, RR 20, O2 sat 98% on room air
General: 58yo female appearing anxious and uncomfortable, diaphoretic, lying in bed, able to speak in full sentences
HEENT: Normocephalic, atraumatic. PERRL, EOMI. MMM (moist mucous membranes). OP clear.
Neck: Supple, no JVD, no carotid bruits appreciated (difficult to assess given urgency)
Cardiovascular: Tachycardic, regular rhythm, normal S1/S2, no murmurs/rubs/gallops appreciated on rapid exam. PMI not displaced. Distal pulses 2+ and symmetric in all extremities.
Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation bilaterally, no wheezes/rales/rhonchi. Respiratory effort non-labored.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, non-distended, normoactive bowel sounds
Extremities: Warm, well-perfused, no cyanosis, clubbing, or edema. Bilateral radial and dorsalis pedis pulses 2+. Cap refill <2 sec.
Skin: Diaphoretic. No rashes or lesions.
Neurologic: Alert and oriented x3, appropriately anxious. CN II-XII grossly intact on rapid assessment. Moving all extremities.

LABORATORY DATA (ED, drawn 06:30 AM):
Cardiac Enzymes:
- Troponin I: 0.05 ng/mL (elevated, normal <0.04) [serial troponins to follow]
- CK: 89 U/L (normal)

Performed by: Dr. Michael Thompson (attending), Dr. James Rodriguez (fellow)

Osteoporosis - critical teaching:

Explained: You have very weak bones (osteoporosis)
Why you broke hip from simple fall: Normal bones don't break from standing-height fall, but weak bones do

Much better than oral pills (patient stopped oral pills before)
